natural problem: There are integers $b,c$ for which both roots of the polynomial $x^2-x-1$ are also roots of the polynomial $x^5-bx-c$. Determine the product $bc$.
natural solution: Let $r$ be a root of $x^2-x-1$. Then, rearranging, we have $$r^2 = r+1.$$Multiplying both sides by $r$ and substituting gives \begin{align} r^3 &= r^2+r \\ &= (r+1)+r \\ &= 2r+1. \end{align}Repeating this process twice more, we have

\begin{align} r^4 &= r(2r+1) \\ &= 2r^2+r \\ &= 2(r+1)+r \\ &= 3r+2 \end{align}and \begin{align} r^5 &= r(3r+2) \\ &= 3r^2+2r \\ &= 3(r+1)+2r \\ &= 5r+3. \end{align}Thus, each root of $x^2-x-1$ is also a root of $x^5-5x-3$, which gives $bc = 5\cdot 3 = \boxed{15}$.
(It is left to the reader to investigate why this answer is unique.)

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b c :: int and p q :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = x powr 2 - x - 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. q x = x powr 5 - b * x - c"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. p x = 0 \<longrightarrow> q x = 0"
shows  "b * c = 15"

assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = x powr 2 - x - 1"

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b c :: int and P Q :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 2 - x - 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 5 - b * x - c"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. poly (P x) = 0 \<longrightarrow> poly (Q x) = 0"
shows  "b * c = 15"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are integers $b,c$ for which both roots of the polynomial $x^2-x-1$ are also roots of the polynomial $x^5-bx-c$. Determine the product $bc$. The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 Let $r$ be a root of $x^2-x-1$. Then, rearranging, we have $$r^2 = r+1.$$Multiplying both sides by $r$ and substituting gives \begin{align} r^3 &= r^2+r \\ &= (r+1)+r \\ &= 2r+1. \end{align}Repeating this process twice more, we have
 \begin{align} r^4 &= r(2r+1) \\ &= 2r^2+r \\ &= 2(r+1)+r \\ &= 3r+2 \end{align}and \begin{align} r^5 &= r(3r+2) \\ &= 3r^2+2r \\ &= 3(r+1)+2r \\ &= 5r+3. \end{align}Thus, each root of $x^2-x-1$ is also a root of $x^5-5x-3$, which gives $bc = 5\cdot 3 = \boxed{15}$.
 (It is left to the reader to investigate why this answer is unique.)
 *)

and h2 : "\<forall> x. poly (P x) = 0 \<longrightarrow> poly (Q x) = 0"
shows  "b * c = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
